docs.title: Smyles Station - Kids Game Kiosk
docs.text: Welcome to Smyles Station! This is a kid-friendly computer kiosk designed to give children safe access to educational games and websites.

docs.title: What It Does
docs.text:
Think of Smyles Station as a safe, controlled computer environment perfect for libraries, schools, and community centers. Here's what it helps you do:

  • Keep Kids Safe: Only shows websites you approve - kids can't visit anything else
  • Manage Time: Set time limits so each child gets a fair turn
  • Close on Time: Automatically turns off the computer at closing time
  • Track Usage: See which games are most popular and how long kids play
  • Lock It Down: Prevents kids from accessing system settings, downloads, or other programs

docs.title: Q: What is Smyles Station?
docs.text: A: Smyles Station is a kid-friendly kiosk application that provides safe, time-limited access to educational games and websites. It's designed for libraries, schools, and community centers.

docs.title: Q: What do I need to run Smyles Station?
docs.text: A: - Windows 10+ or Ubuntu 20.04+ (Linux) - 4 GB RAM minimum (8 GB recommended) - Internet connection - See Hardware Requirements for full details

docs.title: Q: How do I install Smyles Station?
docs.text: A: See the Installation Guide for step-by-step instructions for Windows and Linux.

docs.title: Q: Is Smyles Station free?
docs.text: A: Yes, Smyles Station is open source and free to use.

docs.title: Q: How long is each session?
docs.text:
A: The default session length is configured in Admin Settings. Common defaults are: - 30 minutes (typical for libraries) - 45 minutes (classroom use) - 60 minutes (extended use)

You set this once in Admin Dashboard -> Settings -> "Session Time Limit"

docs.title: Q: Can I change the time limit for individual sessions?
docs.text: A: No, the current design uses a single default time limit for all sessions. All children get the same amount of time for fairness.

docs.title: Q: Can kids extend their session time?
docs.text: A: No. Time limits are enforced automatically and cannot be extended by users. This ensures fairness for all children.

docs.title: Q: What happens when the session timer expires?
docs.text: A: 1. 5 minutes before end: Yellow warning appears 2. 1 minute before end: Red warning appears 3. At zero: Session ends automatically 4. "Session Expired" message shows briefly 5. Returns to welcome screen for next child

docs.title: Q: Can kids switch games during their session?
docs.text: A: Yes! Kids can click "X Exit Game" to return to the game selection screen and choose a different game. The session timer continues running - no extra time is added.

docs.title: Q: How do I set session time to unlimited?
docs.text:
A: Set "Session Time Limit" to 0 in Admin Dashboard. The timer won't display and sessions won't auto-end.

Warning: Unlimited sessions aren't recommended for public use as they prevent fair access.

docs.title: Q: What's the default admin password?
docs.text: A: admin.

docs.title: Q: How do I access Admin Settings?
docs.text: A: 1. On the welcome screen, click the Settings button at the top right 2. Select Admin Settings 3. Enter your admin password

docs.title: Q: I forgot my admin password. What do I do?
docs.text:
A: 1. Close Smyles Station completely 2. Navigate to the config directory: - Windows: Press Win + R, type %APPDATA%\smyles-station\, press Enter - Linux: ~/.config/smyles-station/ 3. Delete the file admin-config.json 4. Restart Smyles Station 5. Create a new password

Warning: This resets ALL settings, not just the password. Your site list (in sites.json) is preserved.

docs.title: Q: How do I change the admin password?
docs.text: A: 1. Access Admin Dashboard 2. Go to the Settings or Password tab 3. Enter current password 4. Enter new password twice 5. Click Save

docs.title: Q: Can I have multiple admin passwords?
docs.text: A: No, there's only one admin password for the entire system.

docs.title: Q: The Settings button doesn't appear. Where is it?
docs.text: A: The Settings button is at the top right of the welcome screen (the screen with the big Play button). If you're in a game session, end the session first.

docs.title: Q: How do I add games?
docs.text:
A: 1. Access Admin Dashboard 2. Go to Sites tab 3. Click Add New Site 4. Enter the full URL (e.g., https://pbskids.org) 5. App fetches the site name and icon automatically 6. Click Save

See Configuration Guide for details.

docs.title: Q: Why won't a game load?
docs.text:
Possible causes:

No internet: Check your internet connection

Site is down: Try accessing the site in a regular browser

Blocked by firewall: Some firewalls block embedded browsers. Check firewall settings.

Site blocks embedding: Some websites prevent being displayed in embedded views for security. These sites won't work in Smyles Station.

Wrong URL: Verify the URL is correct in Admin Dashboard -> Sites

docs.title: Q: A game loads but looks broken or doesn't work properly.
docs.text:
A: Some websites use features that don't work well in embedded views. Try: 1. Re-fetching the site info in Admin Dashboard 2. Checking if the site works in a regular browser 3. Finding an alternative similar site

Not all websites are compatible with embedded viewing.

docs.title: Q: Can kids download files or install programs?
docs.text: A: No. File downloads are blocked by design. Kids cannot install programs or download files through Smyles Station.

docs.title: Q: How do I remove a game?
docs.text: A: 1. Admin Dashboard -> Sites tab 2. Find the site 3. Click the Delete button (trash icon) 4. Confirm deletion

docs.title: Q: The game icons don't show up.
docs.text: A: Some sites don't provide icons (favicons). You can: - Upload a custom icon when editing the site - Leave it with a generic placeholder - Re-fetch site info to try again

docs.title: Q: How do I reorder games?
docs.text: A: In Admin Dashboard -> Sites tab, drag and drop the site tiles to reorder them. Changes save automatically.

docs.title: Q: Smyles Station won't start.
docs.text:
Check: - System requirements are met (see Hardware Requirements) - All Windows updates are installed - Try restarting your computer - Check error logs: - Windows: %APPDATA%\smyles-station\logs\ - Linux: ~/.config/smyles-station/logs/

Try reinstalling if the issue persists.

docs.title: Q: The application crashes frequently.
docs.text: Try: 1. Disable hardware acceleration: - Admin Dashboard -> Settings -> Uncheck "Enable Hardware Acceleration" 2. Update graphics drivers 3. Check available RAM (4 GB minimum, 8 GB recommended) 4. Review logs for error messages

docs.title: Q: The Play button doesn't work.
docs.text: Check: - Internet connection is working - Application isn't frozen (try clicking Settings button) - Restart Smyles Station - Check console for errors (if in development mode)

docs.title: Q: Games load slowly.
docs.text:
Possible causes: - Slow internet connection (need 5+ Mbps) - Many browser tabs/windows open - Insufficient RAM - Site itself is slow

Try: - Close other programs - Test internet speed - Try different games to see if all are slow

docs.title: Q: The timer doesn't appear.
docs.text: Check: - Session Time Limit is set to a value greater than 0 - Admin Dashboard -> Settings -> "Session Time Limit" - If set to 0, timer won't display (unlimited session)

docs.title: Q: The session doesn't end when timer reaches zero.
docs.text: This is a bug. Workaround: 1. Click "End Session" button manually 2. Report the issue on GitHub 3. Check logs: %APPDATA%\smyles-station\logs\

docs.title: Q: Scheduled shutdown isn't working.
docs.text:
Check: 1. Admin Dashboard -> Schedule tab 2. Verify day is enabled (checkmark) 3. Verify time is correct (24-hour format: 8 PM = 20:00) 4. Click "Save" or "Update" after making changes 5. Smyles Station must be running at shutdown time

Linux only: May need special permissions. See Scheduled Shutdown Guide.

docs.title: Q: Where are configuration files stored?
docs.text:
A: - Windows: %APPDATA%\smyles-station\ - Full path: C:\Users\[YourUsername]\AppData\Roaming\smyles-station\ - Linux: ~/.config/smyles-station/

Files include: - config.json - Settings and admin password - sites.json - Game list - schedule.json - Shutdown schedule - stats.json - Usage statistics

docs.title: Q: Is Smyles Station safe for children?
docs.text: A: Yes. Smyles Station includes multiple security layers: - Only whitelisted sites can be accessed - No file downloads - Developer tools disabled - Cannot exit without admin password - Time limits prevent excessive use

docs.title: Q: Can kids access websites not on the approved list?
docs.text: A: No. Only sites added to the whitelist in Admin Dashboard can be accessed. Kids cannot navigate to other sites.

docs.title: Q: Can kids access Windows or other programs?
docs.text: A: From within a session, no - fullscreen mode and keyboard blocking prevent this. However, Smyles Station is designed to allow admin exit to Windows desktop with a password. For maximum lockdown, see Kiosk Mode Guide.

docs.title: Q: What if a kid finds inappropriate content on an approved site?
docs.text: A: 1. Immediately end the session (click "End Session") 2. Investigate what they saw 3. Remove the site: Admin Dashboard -> Sites -> Delete 4. Report the issue to the site owner and/or Smyles Station developers

docs.title: Q: How do I prevent kids from closing Smyles Station?
docs.text:
A: Built-in protections block common exit methods (Alt+F4, Alt+Tab, Windows key).

For complete lockdown where kids cannot access Windows at all, see OS-Level Security.

docs.title: Q: Can I monitor which games kids are playing?
docs.text:
A: Yes. Admin Dashboard -> Statistics tab shows: - Most popular games - Total time played - Session history - Usage patterns

You can also export this data as CSV.

docs.title: Q: How secure is the admin password?
docs.text:
A: The password is hashed (encrypted) and stored locally. Only someone with physical access to the computer could attempt to reset it (by deleting config files).

Best practices: - Use a strong password - Don't share it with children - Change it periodically - Store it securely but accessible to all authorized staff

docs.title: Q: How do I view usage statistics?
docs.text: A: 1. Admin Dashboard -> Statistics tab 2. View summary data: - Total sessions - Completed sessions - Total time used - Most popular games

docs.title: Q: Can I export usage data?
docs.text: A: Yes. In Statistics tab, click "Download CSV" to export data for use in Excel or other spreadsheet programs.

docs.title: Q: How do I reset/clear statistics?
docs.text:
A: Currently, statistics automatically accumulate. To clear: 1. Close Smyles Station 2. Navigate to config directory 3. Delete stats.json 4. Restart Smyles Station

Warning: This permanently deletes all usage history.

docs.title: Q: Can I customize the appearance/colors?
docs.text: A: Not currently through the UI. Advanced users can modify CSS files, but this requires technical knowledge and may break with updates.

docs.title: Q: Can I add password protection to individual games?
docs.text: A: No, all approved games are equally accessible once a session starts.

docs.title: Q: Can I have different time limits for different age groups?
docs.text: A: Not currently. All sessions use the same default time limit.

docs.title: Q: Does Smyles Station work offline?
docs.text: A: No, an internet connection is required as the games are web-based.

docs.title: Q: Can I host my own games instead of using external websites?
docs.text: A: Yes, if you have a local web server, you can add http://localhost:port or local IP addresses to the site list.

docs.title: Q: Can I white-label or rebrand Smyles Station?
docs.text: A: Smyles Station is open source. Advanced users can modify branding, but this requires technical knowledge of Electron and React.

docs.title: Setting Up Automatic Shutdowns
docs.text: This guide will help you set up your kiosk to automatically turn off at specific times each day - perfect for making sure the computer shuts down when the library closes!

docs.title: What This Does
docs.text:
Think of this like setting an alarm clock, but instead of waking you up, it turns the computer off:

  • Set different shutdown times for each day of the week
  • The computer will give a 10-minute warning before shutting down
  • The computer will completely power off (not just close the program)
  • Once the countdown starts, it cannot be stopped

Example: Set Monday through Friday to shut down at 8:00 PM, and leave weekends off.

docs.title: Step 1: Open the Admin Settings
docs.text:
1. On the kiosk computer, press these three keys at the same time:
  2. Ctrl + Alt + Shift + A
  3. Enter your admin password (default is admin if you haven't changed it)
  4. You'll see a page with various settings

docs.title: Step 2: Find the Shutdown Schedule
docs.text:
1. Scroll down the page until you see "Scheduled Shutdown"
  2. You'll see a list of all seven days of the week

docs.title: Step 3: Choose Your Shutdown Days
docs.text:
For each day of the week, you can:

Turn it ON or OFF: - ✅ Checked box = Computer will shut down on this day - ☐ Unchecked box = Computer will NOT shut down on this day

Set the time: - Click the time box - Choose the hour and minute when you want the shutdown to happen - Use 24-hour time (examples below)

Time Examples: - 8:00 PM = 20:00 - 9:00 PM = 21:00 - 6:00 PM = 18:00 - 10:00 PM = 22:00

docs.title: Step 4: Save Your Changes
docs.text:
1. After setting up all your days, scroll to the bottom
  2. Click the blue "Update Shutdown Schedule" button
  3. You should see a green success message

docs.title: Example Setup
docs.text:
Here's a typical library schedule:

Monday:    ✅ Turned ON    20:00 (8:00 PM)
Tuesday:   ✅ Turned ON    20:00 (8:00 PM)
Wednesday: ✅ Turned ON    20:00 (8:00 PM)
Thursday:  ✅ Turned ON    20:00 (8:00 PM)
Friday:    ✅ Turned ON    22:00 (10:00 PM) - Late night!
Saturday:  ☐ Turned OFF
Sunday:    ☐ Turned OFF

This setup means: - Monday through Thursday: Shuts down at 8 PM - Friday: Shuts down at 10 PM (because of extended hours) - Saturday and Sunday: No automatic shutdown (library closed)

docs.title: What Happens When Shutdown Time Arrives
10 Minutes Before
docs.text: A bright yellow warning screen appears that says: - "System Shutdown Scheduled" - Shows a countdown timer - Reminds everyone to save their work

docs.title: When Time's Up
docs.text:
• The computer counts down to zero
  • Everything closes automatically
  • The computer powers off completely

docs.title: Special Setup for Linux Computers
docs.text:
If you're using Windows: You're all set! No extra steps needed.

If you're using Linux: The computer needs special permission to shut itself down. You'll need to ask your IT department or a technical person to help with this one-time setup.

docs.title: What to Tell Your IT Person
docs.text:
"We need to allow the kiosk user account to shut down the computer. Please set up either PolicyKit rules or sudoers permissions for system shutdown."

They can refer to the technical notes at the bottom of this page for exact instructions.

docs.title: "What if someone is in the middle of a game?"
docs.text: The 10-minute warning gives them time to finish up and save. However, the shutdown WILL happen, so it's important to: - Post signs about closing times - Make sure kids know when to finish up - Train staff to give verbal warnings at closing time

docs.title: "What if I forget to turn it off on a holiday?"
docs.text: The computer will shut down as scheduled. To prevent this: - Uncheck that day ahead of time - Or simply turn off the computer manually before the scheduled time

docs.title: "Can I stop it once the warning starts?"
docs.text: No - once the 10-minute countdown begins, it cannot be cancelled. This ensures the kiosk always shuts down on time.

docs.title: "What if the computer is already off?"
docs.text: Nothing happens! The schedule only works when the computer is on and the program is running. It won't turn on a computer that's already off.

docs.title: "What if I need to change the time?"
docs.text: Just open the admin panel again (Ctrl+Alt+Shift+A), change the time, and click "Update Shutdown Schedule."

docs.title: Before You Start
docs.text:
• Decide your closing times for each day
  • Consider: Do you have different hours on different days?
  • Make sure you account for time to clean up

docs.title: Communication is Key
docs.text:
• Put up signs at the kiosk showing shutdown times
  • Tell your staff about the automatic shutdown schedule
  • Remind kids when closing time is approaching (5-10 minutes before)

docs.title: Good Scheduling Practices
docs.text:
• Set shutdowns 15-30 minutes AFTER closing time (gives buffer for stragglers)
  • Don't schedule shutdowns during hours you're actually open
  • Test new schedules on a quiet day first

docs.title: "It's not shutting down!"
docs.text: Check these things: 1. Is there a checkmark next to that day? 2. Is the time set correctly? (Remember: 8 PM = 20:00) 3. Did you click "Update Shutdown Schedule" after making changes? 4. Is the program actually running?

docs.title: "I don't see the warning"
docs.text: The warning should appear 10 minutes before shutdown. If you don't see it: - Make sure you're testing at least 11 minutes before the scheduled time - The warning is a large yellow box that covers the whole screen - hard to miss!

docs.title: "On Linux, I get an error when it tries to shut down"
docs.text: This means the computer doesn't have permission to shut itself down. You'll need help from your IT department (see the "Special Setup for Linux" section above).

docs.title: Need More Help?
docs.text:
• Check with your IT department
  • Ask the person who installed the kiosk software
  • Refer to the technical documentation in the Developer section

docs.title: Linux Permission Setup
docs.text:
The kiosk needs permission to execute system shutdown commands.

Option 1: PolicyKit (Recommended)

Create /etc/polkit-1/rules.d/50-kiosk-shutdown.rules:

polkit.addRule(function(action, subject) {
    if (action.id == "org.freedesktop.login1.power-off" &&
        subject.user == "KIOSK_USERNAME") {
        return polkit.Result.YES;
    }
});

Option 2: Sudoers

Create /etc/sudoers.d/kiosk-shutdown:

KIOSK_USERNAME ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD: /sbin/shutdown, /bin/systemctl poweroff

Replace KIOSK_USERNAME with the actual username running the kiosk application.

docs.title: Test Mode
docs.text:
For testing without actual shutdowns:

SHUTDOWN_DRY_RUN=true npm start

docs.text: Settings stored in: ~/.config/Electron/admin-config.json (or %APPDATA% on Windows)

docs.text: This guide covers the day-to-day operation of Smyles Station, including starting sessions, monitoring time, and handling common scenarios.

docs.title: The Welcome Screen
docs.text:
When Smyles Station launches, children see a simple welcome screen with:

  • Large Play Button - The main button to start
  • Settings button - In the top left

docs.title: Starting a Session
docs.text:
For children:

  1. Click the Play button
  2. Session starts automatically with the default time limit
  3. Game selection screen appears

That's it! No complicated menus or choices - kids just click play.

docs.title: Selecting a Game
docs.text:
After clicking play:

  1. Grid of available games appears
  2. Each tile shows:
  3. Game icon
  4. Game name
  5. Click any game to start playing
  6. Game loads immediately

docs.title: Session Duration
docs.text:
Sessions use the default time limit configured in admin settings.

To change the default: 1. Access Admin Dashboard (Settings button -> Admin Settings) 2. Enter admin password 3. Go to Settings tab 4. Change "Session Time Limit" 5. Save

Common durations: - 30 minutes (recommended for libraries) - 45 minutes (classroom periods) - 60 minutes (longer sessions)

docs.title: What the Child Sees
docs.text: While playing a game: - Game runs fullscreen - Timer visible in corner (if time limit set) - "End Session" button available - "Exit Game" button (top left) - returns to game selection

docs.title: Game View Controls
docs.text:
Exit Game button ( Exit Game): - Located in top left corner - Returns to game selection screen - Session timer continues running - Can choose a different game

End Session button: - Visible with timer display - Click to end entire session early - Returns to welcome screen (Play button) - Next child can start fresh

Timer Display: - Shows remaining time: "23:45" (mm:ss format) - Updates every second - Turns red in final minute - Only visible if time limit is set

docs.title: What Staff Can See
docs.text:
From a distance: - Child is engaged with game - Timer shows remaining time (if visible) - No intervention needed

Staff cannot: - See which specific game is being played without approaching - Pause the timer - Extend time (must be done via admin settings before session starts)

docs.title: Switching Games
docs.text:
Children can switch games freely:

  1. Click "X Exit Game" (top left)
  2. Returns to game selection screen
  3. Click different game
  4. Session timer continues - no time added

Session time continues across game switches - encourages thoughtful choices.

docs.title: Session Warnings
docs.text:
1 minute before end: - Warning appears - Timer turns red - Time to save and wrap up

When timer reaches zero: - Game automatically closes - "Session Expired" message appears briefly - Returns to welcome screen (Play button) - Ready for next child

docs.title: Automatic End (Normal)
docs.text:
When the session timer expires:

  1. Current game closes
  2. "Session Expired" message displays
  3. Returns to welcome screen after a few seconds
  4. Next child can click Play button

This is the standard, fair way sessions end.

docs.title: Manual End
docs.text:
If a child finishes early:

  1. Click End Session button (with timer)
  2. Session ends immediately
  3. Browser data is cleared
  4. Returns to welcome screen
  5. Next child can use computer

docs.title: Technical Issue During Session
docs.text:
Game won't load: 1. Click "X Exit Game" 2. Try different game 3. If all games fail, check internet connection

Smyles Station crashes: 1. Restart Smyles Station 2. Child can start new session 3. Previous session time is lost (by design - prevents exploits)

docs.title: Accessing Admin Functions
docs.text:
From welcome screen:

  1. Click Settings button at top right
  2. Choose Admin Settings
  3. Enter admin password
  4. Access full Admin Dashboard

From here you can: - Add/remove games - View usage statistics - Change session time limit - Configure shutdown schedule - Change admin password

docs.title: Closing Smyles Station
docs.text:
To exit to Windows desktop:

  1. On welcome screen, click Settings
  2. Select Close Application
  3. Enter admin password
  4. Smyles Station closes
  5. Computer returns to normal Windows

Use when: - Need to use computer for other tasks - Performing maintenance - End of day (or let scheduled shutdown handle it)

docs.title: Viewing Usage Data
docs.text:
1. Access Admin Dashboard (Settings -> Admin Settings + password)
  2. Go to Statistics tab
  3. See:
  4. Total sessions
  5. Most popular games
  6. Total time used
  7. Usage patterns

Use this data to: - Add more similar games to popular ones - Remove unused games - Understand peak times - Report to stakeholders

docs.title: Session Logs
docs.text: Recent session history shows: - Date and time - Duration - Which games were accessed - How session ended (time expired vs. manual)

docs.title: Session won't start (Play button doesn't work)
docs.text: Check: - Internet connection - Smyles Station is responding (not frozen) - Try restarting Smyles Station

docs.title: Timer not visible
docs.text:
Possible causes: - Session time limit set to 0/unlimited - Display issue

Fix: - Check Admin Settings -> Session Time Limit - Should be set to desired minutes (e.g., 30)

docs.title: Session doesn't end automatically
docs.text:
This is a bug - should not happen.

Workaround: 1. Click "End Session" button manually 2. Report the issue 3. Check logs in %APPDATA%\smyles-station\logs\

docs.title: Can't exit game
docs.text: Try: 1. Click "X Exit Game" button (top right) 2. Or click "End Session" button 3. If both fail, restart Smyles Station

docs.title: Games won't load
docs.text: Check: - Internet connection working? - Try different game - Restart Smyles Station - Check Admin Dashboard -> Sites for URL errors

docs.title: For Children
docs.text:
How to Play:

1. Click the big Play button 
2. Choose your game
3. Have fun!
4. Click "Exit Game" to pick a different game
5. Click "End Session" when you're done

docs.title: For Staff
docs.text:

Switching games: "X Exit Game" button (top right)
Ending early: "End Session" button
Admin access: Settings -> Admin Settings -> Password
Close app: Settings -> Close Application -> Password

Location: packages/main/src/modules/SessionModule.ts

Responsibilities: - Start/end sessions - Track remaining time - Emit warnings before expiry - Clean up on session end

class SessionModule {
  private currentSession: {
    startTime: number;
    duration: number;
    timer: NodeJS.Timeout;
  } | null = null;

  async startSession(duration: number) {
    this.currentSession = {
      startTime: Date.now(),
      duration,
      timer: setTimeout(() => this.endSession(), duration),
    };
  }
}

docs.title: Why Electron?
docs.text:
Pros: - Cross-platform (Windows, Linux, macOS) - Sandboxed browser views for untrusted content - Mature security model - Rich ecosystem

Cons: - Larger bundle size - More memory usage

Decision: Security and cross-platform support outweigh resource concerns for a kiosk application.

docs.title: Why Monorepo?
docs.text: Benefits: - Clear separation of concerns - Independent testing per package - Shared TypeScript configuration - Type safety across boundaries

docs.title: Why IPC over Direct Imports?
docs.text:
Renderer cannot import main process code due to security:

// Not possible (renderer is sandboxed)
import {startSession} from '../../main/src/modules/SessionModule';

// Must use IPC bridge
import {startSession} from '@app/preload';
await startSession(siteUrl, duration);

docs.title: Why Module Pattern?
docs.text:
Benefits: - Self-contained features - Easy to test in isolation - Clear ownership - Simple to add/remove features

Example: 

// Adding a new feature is just instantiating a module
new MyNewFeatureModule(browserWindow);

docs.title: 1. Main Process Features
docs.text:
To add a new feature to the main process:

  1. Create a new module in packages/main/src/modules/: 

    // packages/main/src/modules/MyFeatureModule.ts
import {BrowserWindow, ipcMain} from 'electron';

export class MyFeatureModule {
  constructor(private readonly browserWindow: BrowserWindow) {
    this.setupIpcHandlers();
  }

  private setupIpcHandlers() {
    ipcMain.handle('my-feature:action', async () => {
      // Implementation
      return result;
    });
  }
}

  2. Register the module in packages/main/src/index.ts: 

    import {MyFeatureModule} from './modules/MyFeatureModule';

// In the app initialization
new MyFeatureModule(browserWindow);

  1. Add the function to packages/preload/src/index.ts: 

    export async function myFeatureAction(): Promise<Result> {
  return ipcRenderer.invoke('my-feature:action');
}

  2. Update TypeScript types in packages/renderer/src/electron.d.ts:

  myFeatureAction: () => Promise<Result>;
}

  3. Use in React components: 

    import {myFeatureAction} from '@app/preload';

const result = await myFeatureAction();

docs.title: Security Guidelines
docs.text: Smyles Station is designed for use with children, so security is critical.

docs.title: Security Principles
docs.text:
1. Never expose Node.js APIs to renderer - Always use the preload bridge
  2. Validate all inputs - Especially from IPC and user input
  3. Sanitize URLs - Prevent navigation to unauthorized sites
  4. Use context isolation - Already enabled, don't disable it
  5. Enable sandbox - Keep renderer processes sandboxed
  6. Minimize privileges - Only request permissions you need

docs.title: Security Checklist
docs.text:
Before adding new features:

  • [ ] Does this expose any system APIs to the renderer?
  • [ ] Are all IPC handlers validated and sanitized?
  • [ ] Could this be used to bypass URL restrictions?
  • [ ] Does this handle user input safely?
  • [ ] Could this be exploited by malicious web content?

docs.title: Common Security Pitfalls
docs.text:
DON'T: 

// Exposing shell access to renderer
ipcMain.handle('run-command', (_, cmd) => {
  exec(cmd); // Dangerous!
});

DO: 

// Specific, validated operations
ipcMain.handle('shutdown-system', async () => {
  // Verify admin authentication first
  if (!isAdminAuthenticated()) return;

  // Execute specific, safe operation
  await shutdownSystem();
});

docs.text: This guide covers how to customize Smyles Station for your specific needs.

docs.title: Table of Contents
docs.text:

docs.title: Accessing Admin Dashboard
docs.text: The Admin Dashboard is where all configuration happens.

docs.title: Opening the Dashboard
docs.text:
Three ways to access:

  1. From main screen: Click the Admin button
  2. Keyboard shortcut: Press Ctrl+Shift+A
  3. During a session: Press Ctrl+Shift+Q to exit first, then access admin

All methods require your admin password.

docs.title: Dashboard Layout
docs.text:
The Admin Dashboard has several tabs:

  • Sites - Add, edit, and manage websites
  • Statistics - View usage data
  • Settings - Configure session defaults and preferences
  • Schedule - Set up automatic shutdowns
  • Password - Change admin password

docs.title: Adding a New Site
docs.text:
1. Open Admin Dashboard
  2. Click Sites tab
  3. Click Add New Site button
  4. Enter the website URL:
  5. Must be complete URL (e.g., https://pbskids.org)
  6. Include https:// or http://
  7. Click Fetch Info or press Enter
  8. The app will automatically retrieve:
  9. Site title
  10. Site favicon/icon
  11. Review and click Save

The site will now appear on the main selection screen.

docs.title: Editing a Site
docs.text:
1. In the Sites tab, find the site
  2. Click the Edit button (pencil icon)
  3. You can modify:
  4. Display name
  5. URL
  6. Icon (upload custom or re-fetch)
  7. Visibility (show/hide)
  8. Click Save Changes

docs.title: Reordering Sites
docs.text:
Sites appear on the main screen in the order you arrange them:

  1. In the Sites tab
  2. Drag and drop sites to reorder
  3. Changes save automatically
  4. Kids will see sites in this order

Tip: Put the most popular sites at the top.

docs.title: Hiding Sites
docs.text:
To temporarily hide a site without deleting it:

  1. Edit the site
  2. Toggle Visible to OFF
  3. Save

The site won't appear to kids but remains in your list.

docs.title: Removing Sites
docs.text:
To permanently delete a site:

  1. In the Sites tab
  2. Click the Delete button (trash icon)
  3. Confirm deletion
  4. The site is removed from the list

docs.title: Troubleshooting Site Issues
docs.text:
Site won't load: - Verify URL is correct and complete - Some sites don't work in embedded views - Try accessing directly in browser first - Check internet connection

Icon doesn't load: - Some sites don't provide favicons - Upload a custom icon instead - Or use a generic placeholder

Site loads but looks broken: - Some sites use features incompatible with embedded browsers - May need to be accessed in full browser instead - Consider alternative similar sites

docs.title: Session Settings
docs.text: Configure default behavior for all sessions.

docs.title: Default Session Duration
docs.text:
1. Admin Dashboard -> Settings tab
  2. Find Default Session Time
  3. Choose duration:
  4. 15 minutes (short sessions)
  5. 30 minutes (recommended for most)
  6. 45 minutes (classroom periods)
  7. 60 minutes (longer sessions)
  8. Custom (enter your own)
  9. Click Save

Note: This is the default - you can override per-session when starting.

docs.title: Warning Time
docs.text:
How early to warn users before session expires:

  1. Settings tab
  2. Warning Time setting
  3. Recommended: 5 minutes
  4. Range: 1-10 minutes
  5. Save

The warning shows a countdown timer and alert sound.

docs.title: Session End Behavior
docs.text:
Choose what happens when a session ends:

Return to Selection Screen (Default): - Session closes - Returns to main site selection - Kid can start another session

Exit to Desktop (Optional): - Session closes - Smyles Station exits - Returns to Windows desktop - Requires restart for next use

Lock Computer (Optional): - Session closes - Computer locks - Requires password to unlock

Configure in Settings -> Session End Behavior

docs.title: Shutdown Schedule
docs.text: Configure automatic computer shutdown for closing time.

docs.title: Setting Up Scheduled Shutdowns
docs.text:
1. Admin Dashboard -> Schedule tab
  2. You'll see each day of the week
  3. For each day you want automatic shutdown:
  4. Toggle Enabled to ON
  5. Set the shutdown time
  6. Save

Example: - Monday-Friday: 8:00 PM (library closing) - Saturday: 6:00 PM - Sunday: OFF (closed)

docs.title: How Scheduled Shutdown Works
docs.text:
10 minutes before shutdown time: - Warning appears on screen - Sound alert plays - Timer counts down

When shutdown time arrives: - Active sessions end automatically - Computer shuts down - Cannot be cancelled (by design)

Important: Make sure shutdown time is AFTER your actual closing time to give staff time to finish up.

docs.title: Platform Support
docs.text:
Windows: - Full support - Uses shutdown /s /t 0 command - Computer powers off completely

Linux: - Full support - Uses shutdown -h now command - May require sudo permissions

docs.title: Disabling Scheduled Shutdown
docs.text:
To turn off for a specific day:

  1. Schedule tab
  2. Toggle that day to OFF
  3. Save

To disable completely: Turn OFF all days.

docs.title: Changing Your Password
docs.text:
1. Admin Dashboard -> Password tab
  2. Enter current password
  3. Enter new password
  4. Re-enter new password to confirm
  5. Click Change Password

Requirements: - At least 8 characters - Should be memorable but secure - Store in a safe place

docs.title: Password Security Tips
docs.text:
Do: - Use a password manager - Write it down and store securely - Share with authorized staff only - Change periodically

Don't: - Share with kids - Use obvious passwords (like "password123") - Post it publicly visible - Forget to write it down!

docs.title: If You Forget Your Password
docs.text:
Reset method (resets ALL settings):

  1. Exit Smyles Station completely
  2. Open File Explorer
  3. Navigate to %APPDATA%\smyles-station\
  4. Delete config.json
  5. Restart Smyles Station
  6. You'll be prompted to set a new password

Warning: This erases: - Admin password - All added sites - All settings - Usage statistics

Backup recommendation: Regularly backup your config file.

docs.title: Configuration Files
docs.text:
Smyles Station stores settings in:

Windows: %APPDATA%\smyles-station\ Linux: ~/.config/smyles-station/

Files: - config.json - Main configuration - sites.json - Website list - schedule.json - Shutdown schedule - stats.json - Usage statistics

docs.title: Backing Up Configuration
docs.text:
To backup your settings:

  1. Exit Smyles Station
  2. Navigate to config directory
  3. Copy all .json files to safe location
  4. Date the backup

To restore from backup:

  1. Exit Smyles Station
  2. Replace .json files with backup copies
  3. Restart Smyles Station

docs.title: Manual Configuration Editing
docs.text:
Advanced users can edit JSON files directly:

Warning: Incorrect edits can break Smyles Station. Backup first!

Example - Editing sites.json:

{
  "sites": [
    {
      "id": "1",
      "name": "PBS Kids",
      "url": "https://pbskids.org",
      "icon": "https://pbskids.org/favicon.ico",
      "visible": true,
      "order": 0
    }
  ]
}

Only edit if you know what you're doing.

docs.title: Exporting/Importing Configuration
docs.text:
Export configuration to share with other installations:

  1. Backup all .json files as above
  2. Share with other libraries/locations
  3. They can import by copying files

Useful for: - Multiple kiosk stations - Standard site lists across locations - Backing up approved configurations

docs.title: Command Line Options
docs.text:
Smyles Station supports some command line arguments:

# Disable GPU acceleration (if display issues)
smyles-station --disable-gpu

# Start in development mode (shows console)
smyles-station --dev

# Specify custom config directory
smyles-station --config-dir=/path/to/config

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Advanced configuration via environment variables:

# Custom config location
SMYLES_CONFIG_DIR=/custom/path

# Disable automatic updates
SMYLES_NO_UPDATE=1

# Enable debug logging
SMYLES_DEBUG=1

docs.title: Viewing Statistics
docs.text:
1. Admin Dashboard -> Statistics tab
  2. View data:
  3. Total sessions
  4. Total time used
  5. Most popular sites
  6. Usage by day/time

docs.title: Exporting Statistics
docs.text:
To export usage data:

  1. Admin Portal
  2. Scroll to Usage Data
  3. Download CSV
  4. Save file

Use for: - Reporting to stakeholders - Identifying popular content - Planning content additions

docs.title: Clearing Statistics
docs.text:
To reset all statistics:

  1. Admin Portal
  2. Click Clear All Data
  3. Confirm
  4. All usage data is deleted

Warning: This cannot be undone.

docs.title: Changes not saving
docs.text:
• Ensure you have write permissions
  • Check disk space
  • Verify config directory exists
  • Try restarting Smyles Station

docs.title: Settings reset after restart
docs.text:
• Config file may be corrupted
  • Check file permissions
  • Restore from backup

docs.title: Cannot access Admin Dashboard
docs.text:
• Verify password is correct
  • Check Caps Lock is off
  • Use password reset if needed

docs.title: Sites not appearing
docs.text:
• Verify they're marked visible
  • Check they were saved
  • Restart Smyles Station

docs.title: Regular Maintenance
docs.text:
Weekly: - Review usage statistics - Check for new site requests - Test random sites still work

Monthly: - Backup configuration - Review and update site list - Check for Smyles Station updates

Annually: - Change admin password - Audit all sites for appropriateness - Review security settings

docs.title: Site Curation
docs.text:
Guidelines for adding sites: - Educational value - Age-appropriate content - No ads or minimal ads - Works in embedded browser - Safe, trusted sources

Remove sites that: - No longer work - Have become ad-heavy - Changed to inappropriate content - Are never used (check stats)

docs.title: Prerequisites (Hardware)
docs.text: Before installing Smyles Station, make sure you have the right hardware and understand the system requirements.

docs.title: Computer Specifications
docs.text:
Operating System: - Windows 10 or later (64-bit) - Ubuntu 20.04 or later - Other modern Linux distributions

Processor: - Intel Core i3 or equivalent AMD processor - 2.0 GHz or faster

Memory (RAM): - 4 GB minimum - 8 GB recommended (especially for multiple simultaneous games)

Storage: - 500 MB for Smyles Station application - Additional space for temporary files and cache - SSD recommended for better performance

Display: - 1024x768 minimum resolution - 1920x1080 (Full HD) recommended - Touchscreen optional but recommended for younger children

Network: - Internet connection required for web-based games - Wired Ethernet recommended for reliability - WiFi acceptable with strong signal

docs.title: Ideal Kiosk Computer
docs.text:
For the best experience, we recommend:

Desktop Computer: - Modern desktop or all-in-one PC - Intel Core i5 or AMD Ryzen 5 processor - 8 GB RAM - 256 GB SSD - 24" touchscreen monitor (if separate)

Why Desktop over Laptop? - More durable for public use - Easier to secure physically - Better cooling for all-day operation - More ports for peripherals

docs.title: Peripherals
docs.text:
Keyboard: - Wired keyboard recommended (wireless can be disabled by kids) - Spill-resistant or washable design - Consider a silicone cover for protection

Mouse: - Wired optical mouse - Cleanable surface - Large buttons for small hands - Consider a trackball for durability

Touchscreen (Optional but Recommended): - More intuitive for young children - Reduces need for mouse/keyboard - Easier to clean than traditional input devices

docs.title: Internet Connection
docs.text:
Bandwidth: - Minimum: 5 Mbps download - Recommended: 10+ Mbps download - Upload speed less critical

Why you need good bandwidth: - Web-based games stream content - Some educational sites use video - Multiple users may share the connection

docs.title: Network Access
docs.text:
Considerations:

  1. Firewall: Ensure your firewall allows access to whitelisted game sites
  2. Content Filter: Content filters should allow educational game sites
  3. Network Isolation: Consider separate guest network for kiosk
  4. Static IP (optional): Makes remote management easier if needed

docs.title: Power Supply
docs.text:
Requirements: - UPS (Uninterruptible Power Supply) recommended - Protects against power outages during sessions - Prevents data corruption from sudden shutdowns - Allows graceful shutdown during extended outages

Surge Protection: - Minimum: Surge protector power strip - Better: UPS with surge protection - Protects expensive equipment from power surges

docs.title: Power Saving
docs.text:
Smyles Station includes automatic shutdown scheduling, but consider:

  • Set computer to never sleep during operating hours
  • Enable sleep mode after-hours (or use scheduled shutdown)
  • Disable monitor sleep during active sessions
  • Configure wake-on-LAN if you want remote power management

docs.title: New Hardware Costs (Approximate)
docs.text:
Budget Setup ($400-600): - Refurbished desktop computer - Basic monitor - Keyboard and mouse - Surge protector

Mid-Range Setup ($800-1,200): - New desktop computer - 24" touchscreen monitor - Quality peripherals - UPS backup

Premium Setup ($1,500-2,500): - High-performance all-in-one PC - Commercial-grade touchscreen - Kiosk enclosure - Professional installation

docs.title: Cost-Saving Options
docs.text:
1. Refurbished Computers:
  2. Often available from reputable vendors
  3. Meet minimum requirements

  4. Significantly lower cost

  5. Donated Equipment:

  6. Many organizations receive computer donations
  7. Verify meets minimum requirements

  8. May need RAM/SSD upgrades

  9. Existing Hardware:

  10. Repurpose an existing public computer
  11. Install Smyles Station alongside other software
  12. Use kiosk mode to prevent access to other programs

docs.title: Physical Accessibility
docs.text:
• Adjustable-height desk for wheelchair users
  • Touchscreen at reachable height
  • Large-button keyboard for motor difficulties
  • Trackball mouse as alternative to standard mouse

docs.title: Software Accessibility
docs.text: Smyles Station supports: - Screen reader compatibility (via browser) - High-contrast mode (via system settings) - Keyboard navigation - Adjustable text size (in web games)

docs.title: Hardware Checklist
docs.text:
Before proceeding to installation, verify you have:

  • [ ] Computer meeting minimum requirements
  • [ ] Monitor or display (touchscreen recommended)
  • [ ] Keyboard and mouse (wired recommended)
  • [ ] Network connection (wired or WiFi)
  • [ ] Surge protector or UPS
  • [ ] Cable locks or other security measures (if needed)
  • [ ] Appropriate seating for children

docs.title: Common Hardware Questions
docs.text:
Q: Can I use an old laptop? A: Yes, if it meets minimum requirements. Desktop is preferred for durability and security.

Q: Do I need a touchscreen? A: Not required, but highly recommended for younger children.

Q: What about Chromebooks or tablets? A: Smyles Station requires Windows or Linux. Chromebooks and tablets are not currently supported.

Q: Can I use wireless keyboard/mouse? A: Not recommended - tech-savvy kids may disable them. Wired peripherals are more secure.

Q: What if my computer doesn't have enough RAM? A: Many older computers can be upgraded. Check if your computer has available RAM slots and upgrade to at least 8 GB for best performance.

docs.title: Step 1: Download Smyles Station
docs.text:
1. Visit the Smyles Station releases page: GitHub Releases

  2. Right-click the installer and select Run as administrator

  3. If prompted by Windows Security, click Yes to allow

docs.title: Step 3: Follow the Installation Wizard
docs.text:
1. Welcome Screen:

  2. Click Next

  3. Choose Installation Location:

  4. Default location is recommended: C:\Program Files\Smyles Station

  5. Click Next

docs.title: Step 2: Install the Package
docs.text:
For .deb package:

# Navigate to Downloads folder
cd ~/Downloads

# Install using dpkg
sudo dpkg -i Smyles-Station_*.deb

# Fix any dependency issues
sudo apt-get install -f

For AppImage:

# Navigate to Downloads folder

chmod +x Smyles-Station-*.AppImage

sudo mv Smyles-Station-*.AppImage /opt/smyles-station

# Create a desktop entry
cat > ~/.local/share/applications/smyles-station.desktop <<EOF
[Desktop Entry]
Name=Smyles Station
Exec=/opt/smyles-station
Type=Application
Categories=Education;
EOF

docs.title: First Launch Setup
docs.text: Now that Smyles Station is installed, let's configure it:

docs.text:
Windows: - Press Windows key - Type "Smyles Station" - Click the app

Linux: - Open application menu - Find "Smyles Station" - Click to launch

docs.title: Step 2: Initial Configuration
docs.text:
On first launch, you'll see the welcome screen:

  1. Set Admin Password:
  2. Create a strong password (you'll need this to access admin settings)
  3. Confirm the password
  4. Write this password down in a safe place!

  5. Click Continue

  6. Add Your First Game/Website:

Let's make sure everything works:

  1. Click on one of your added sites

  2. Choose a session duration (or use default)

  3. Click Start Session

  4. The game/website should load in fullscreen

  5. You should see a timer in the corner showing remaining time

  6. Press Ctrl+Shift+Q to exit the session (you'll need to enter the admin password)

If everything works, you're ready to proceed!

docs.title: Step 2: Kiosk Mode (Locking it Down)
docs.text: Smyles Station provides two levels of security: application-level (built-in) and optional OS-level lockdown. Choose the level appropriate for your environment.

docs.title: Security Levels
docs.text:
Application-Level Security (Built-in) - Works out of the box - Password-protected exit - Can still access Windows desktop with admin password - Recommended for most users

OS-Level Security (Optional) - Prevents access to Windows entirely - For dedicated kiosk computers only - Maximum security but less flexible - Requires Windows configuration

docs.title: Built-In Protections
docs.text:
Smyles Station automatically provides these security features:

Fullscreen Mode - Game sessions run in fullscreen - Prevents access to other windows

URL Whitelisting - Only approved sites can be accessed - External links blocked - Pop-ups prevented

Password-Protected Exit - Kids cannot exit without admin password - Exit combination: Ctrl+Shift+Q

Keyboard Shortcuts Blocked - Alt+Tab - Cannot switch windows - Alt+F4 - Cannot close application - Windows key - Cannot open Start menu - F11 - Cannot toggle fullscreen - Right-click - Context menus disabled

No Downloads - File downloads blocked - Prevents installing programs

Developer Tools Disabled - F12 (DevTools) blocked - Cannot view page source

Session Time Limits - Automatic logout when time expires - Warning alerts before session ends

docs.title: Initial Setup
docs.text:
Step 1: Set Admin Password

  1. Launch Smyles Station for the first time
  2. Create a strong admin password (at least 8 characters)
  3. Store this password securely - you'll need it to exit sessions!

Step 2: Add Websites

  1. Press Ctrl+Shift+A to open Admin Dashboard
  2. Enter admin password
  3. Click Manage Sites
  4. Add approved websites:
  5. Click Add New Site
  6. Enter URL (e.g., https://pbskids.org)
  7. App fetches title and icon automatically
  8. Click Save

Step 3: Configure Session Settings

  1. In Admin Dashboard -> Settings
  2. Set Default Session Time (recommended: 30-60 minutes)
  3. Set Warning Time (recommended: 5 minutes before end)
  4. Click Save

docs.title: Exiting to Windows Desktop
docs.text:
Administrators can exit Smyles Station at any time:

  1. Press Ctrl+Shift+Q
  2. Enter admin password
  3. Choose Exit to Desktop

The computer returns to normal Windows operation.

docs.title: Testing Application Security
docs.text:
Before use, verify:

  • [ ] Can start a session
  • [ ] Session is fullscreen
  • [ ] Cannot press Alt+Tab to switch windows
  • [ ] Cannot press Windows key
  • [ ] Cannot press Alt+F4 to close
  • [ ] Cannot right-click in browser
  • [ ] Session ends when timer expires
  • [ ] Warning shows before session ends
  • [ ] Ctrl+Shift+Q prompts for password
  • [ ] Correct password exits to desktop

docs.title: OS-Level Security (Optional)
docs.text: For dedicated kiosk computers where you don't want ANY access to Windows.

docs.title: When to Use OS-Level Lockdown
docs.text:
Use this if: - Computer is dedicated solely to Smyles Station - Located in unsupervised public area - Maximum security required - Don't need Windows desktop access

Don't use this if: - Computer has multiple purposes - Staff need regular Windows access - You want flexibility to exit to desktop - Simpler management preferred

docs.title: Option 1: Limited User Account (Recommended)
docs.text:
Create a restricted Windows account for kiosk use:

  1. Create kiosk user:
  2. Settings -> Accounts -> Family & other users
  3. Add someone else to this PC
  4. Create local account (no Microsoft account)

  5. Set as "Standard user" (not Administrator)

  6. Configure auto-start Smyles Station:

  7. Press Win + R, type shell:startup
  8. Create shortcut to Smyles Station

  9. Place in startup folder

  10. Set auto-login (optional):

  11. Press Win + R, type netplwiz
  12. Uncheck "Users must enter a user name and password"
  13. Select kiosk account
  14. Enter password

Benefits: - Kids cannot install programs - Cannot change system settings - Cannot access admin files - Easy to switch back to admin account for maintenance

docs.title: Option 2: Windows Assigned Access (Pro/Enterprise)
docs.text:
Windows 10/11 Pro includes built-in kiosk mode:

  1. Settings -> Accounts -> Family & other users
  2. Set up assigned access
  3. Choose kiosk account
  4. Select Smyles Station as the app

This prevents ALL access to Windows except Smyles Station.

docs.title: Option 3: Group Policy Restrictions (Advanced)
docs.text:
For IT administrators:

gpedit.msc
- User Configuration
- Administrative Templates
- System
- Disable Task Manager
- Disable Command Prompt
- Disable Registry Editor

Only recommended if you know what you're doing.

docs.title: Linux Configuration
docs.text:
Create dedicated kiosk session:

  1. Install required packages: 

    sudo apt install openbox unclutter

  2. Create kiosk user: 

    sudo adduser kiosk

  3. Create custom session: /usr/share/xsessions/kiosk.desktop: 

    [Desktop Entry]
Name=Kiosk
Exec=/usr/local/bin/kiosk-session

  4. Create startup script: /usr/local/bin/kiosk-session: 

    #!/bin/bash
openbox &
while true; do
    smyles-station
    sleep 5
done

docs.title: Emergency Access
docs.text:
If you lock yourself out of a dedicated kiosk:

Windows: - Restart and hold Shift to enter Safe Mode - Login with administrator account - Modify startup settings

Linux: - Restart and select different session at login - Or boot into recovery mode

docs.title: Physical Security
docs.text: Optional physical lockdown: - Cable locks for computer/peripherals - BIOS password to prevent boot changes - Disable USB ports in BIOS (if not needed) - Cover or disable power button

docs.title: Windows User Account Control
docs.text:
For standard Windows profiles:

  1. Create limited "Kids" account
  2. Keep admin account for staff
  3. Kids account cannot:
  4. Install software
  5. Change system settings
  6. Access admin files

docs.title: Network Security
docs.text:
Optional firewall rules: - Whitelist specific domains only - Block everything else - Prevents access even outside Smyles Station

Note: This is advanced and can break other functionality.

docs.title: Public Computer (Standard)
docs.text:
Application-Level Only: - Normal Windows account - Application-level security (built-in) - Can exit to desktop with password - Staff can use computer for other tasks

Setup: - Install Smyles Station - Set admin password - Add approved sites - Done!

docs.title: Dedicated Kiosk
docs.text:
Application + OS-Level: - Limited Windows "kiosk" account - Auto-start Smyles Station - Cannot access Windows desktop - Computer is dedicated to this purpose

Setup: - Create kiosk Windows account - Install Smyles Station - Configure auto-start - Set auto-login (optional) - Test thoroughly

docs.title: Changing Admin Password
docs.text:
To change password:

  1. Open Admin Dashboard (Ctrl+Shift+A)
  2. Enter current password
  3. Settings -> Change Admin Password
  4. Enter current password, then new password twice
  5. Save

If you forget password:

  1. Exit Smyles Station (or restart computer)
  2. Navigate to: %APPDATA%\smyles-station\ (Windows) or ~/.config/smyles-station/ (Linux)
  3. Delete config.json
  4. Restart Smyles Station
  5. Set new password
  6. Warning: This resets ALL settings

docs.title: Kids escaped fullscreen
docs.text:
• Verify keyboard shortcuts are properly blocked
  • Check for OS-level overrides
  • Update to latest version

docs.title: Cannot exit with password
docs.text:
• Ensure Caps Lock is off
  • Try re-entering password carefully
  • Use password reset if forgotten

docs.title: Auto-start not working
docs.text:
• Check shortcut path is correct
  • Verify user permissions
  • Check startup folder location

docs.title: Other programs accessible
docs.text: Application-level security only blocks within Smyles Station: - Use OS-level security for complete lockdown - Or use limited Windows account
